description:
Really really good pizza and an awesome venue. This place hosts a free comedy night every Tuesday so it's a great day to go there and grab a pizza with friends and listen to some really stellar comedy (better than any other free shows I've been to).

I tried both the margarita and marinara pizzas and both are great. The Margherita is thin but cheesy enough and the crust is extremely crispy. The sauce is extremely tasty as well. The marinara pizza is incredible. I'm not a huge fan of pizzas without cheese, but this pizza is an exception. The sauce is super flavorful and goes great with the crust. They also sell pitchers of rosè and white wine and have tons of options for pizzas, making it a great place to go!
author: Sampath D.

description:
To be honest, I used to love this place. Something went wrong this last time
We got a pizza that was very well burnt (see photos) and salad with extremely stale croutons.

Their service remains to be a good one for a busy place, but I was very disappointed with the food this time around
author: Jad A.

description:
The pizza is delicious.  It reminded me of a cross between Zero, Zero's and Ragazza's pizza.  With oven temps over 600 degrees, the pies come out pretty quickly with crispy/crusty edges yet chewy interiors.
We opted for the Short Bridge which is a meat lovers dream with mushrooms included just for the hell of it.
It was enough for two people but, if we were really hungry then two pies would have been an even better option!
 Fort Point Kolsch was our beer of choice.
The pizza menu is really small and there are a few choices for salads but, that's about it.
This is a very casual place.
....very.....casual.....place...
You're going for the pizza.  It's excellent.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Holy Moly. Pizzahacker is still the reigning champ for best pizza in SF and there's no debating it. 

If you're looking for what I would call a hybrid of Napoletana and San Francisco style of pie, it doesn't get any better. Why do I think it's a hybrid you ask? Well, the crust has a nice bit of "sour" influence due to the native yeasts in the air and the ferment that Pizzahacker much use in their process. It's delicious. As far as the sauce, toppings and cheese go...they are tops. Man, I'm starving just writing this review. 

Do it, do it do it!!!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I came here with a group of friends since they have a free Comedy show on Tuesday night (it's in a small cozy area upstairs).
You can order pizza and they'll bring it up to you. The show was hilarious and I would definitely come back for both pizza and comedy :)
author: Miranda N.

description:
Overall I give Pizzahacker 3.5 stars. It's a fun spot, good pizza. Not the best in the city (Una Pizza, you will forever have a place in my heart, even if you moved back to NYC), but I'm really glad I finally got to try this place!

THE WAIT: About 20 min for dinner for three, Saturday night around 7pm. High turnover, we were the only ones waiting. FYI shared tables!

THE SERVICE: Friendly, fun, chill. 

MUST-HAVES: Short Bridge! My favorite of the night, especially if you're craving savory meats.

SALAD
* Intermezzo ($7.36 medium) - 3 stars
This was fine, nothing to go out of your way for. I didn't particularly feel like a salad but people liked this so I ordered it, but I found there were too many chicories, giving it a pretty bitter flavor. 

PIZZA
* Margherita ($13.79) - 3.5 stars
Good classic pizza. Could've used with a little less oil, a little more tomato sauce. 

* Rocket Man ($15.63) - 3.5 stars
 I was excited for an arugula pizza, but the lemon juice was a bit much.

* Short Bridge ($17.47) - 4 stars
Very delicious meat pizza! They were out of Italian Sausage and only had lamb sausage, but this was still great.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The toppings on their pizzas are great but the noteworthy element is their crust. I heard that the mother dough is from Tartine and I believe it. It's a thin crust that has the perfect amount of chewiness and flavor without tasting like card board or Costco pizza.

The Rocket Man is a go-to for me. The arugula that is lightly tossed in a vinaigrette compliments the garlic, fresh mozzarella, farm egg, lemon juice, chili paste and amplifies the crust (subtle sourdough taste, nice balance of chewy and crisp). We ordered it with the homemade sausage, which adds in a nice meaty, salty taste to it all.

The Summer Fave (seasonal) truly tastes like a bite of summer with the blistered tomatoes and topped with lightly dressed arugula and topped with grana.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Pizza review.

Ordered:
Short bridge + Pepperoni
Rocket man + Chorizo - Arugula

Crust - 4
Toppings - 3
Taste (Rocket man) - 5
Taste (Short bridge) - 3

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
It's Uber-Hipster. I was the only person wearing a collared shirt that was neither flannel nor snap front. My blonde waiter had dreadlocks and Carhartts. It's loud and family style open seating. 

But the pizza is amazing. Very thin, crispy crust. I mean thin thin. And the topping balanced nicely. I ordered "short bridge." You have to order from their set menu. I was okay with what was offered. My choice was sopressata, mushroom and Italian sausage plus other stuff I'd never heard of. 

Very tasty. And for the portion size the prize is fair. 

I have no complaints.
author: Tim P.

description: Since becoming vegan (for health reasons) I thought my life with pizza would be very sad. We came here last night and I was THRILLED to have a super tasty, wonderfully crispy and very delicious vegan pizza. I did not miss the cheese one single bit. Can't wait to go again.
author: holly B.

description: I just spent $17 on this top shelf margarita pizza for only six slices! Needless to say, I am very disappointed and will not come back here.  If you look at the picture, how could this be a top shelf pizza for $17!
author: Dale K.

description:
I'm so disappointed tonight from this restaurant. I've had great service and food before but tonight they dropped the bar. I ordered a short bridge to go. First they were disorganized. The guy said your pizza will be coming up soon. I waited between 5 to 10 minutes watching them box up pizzas. I said to someone else about my pizza, which was sitting on the oven getting cold. 
The pizza was small for $19.00 and tasted ok. Part of the crust was over cooked. For 2 people it did not satisfy us. 
Better improve
author: Larry D.

description: Great pizza, very friendly staff, reasonable prices, and free stand-up comedy upstairs on Tuesday nights!
author: Rob U.

description:
We love pizza. We make it at home from the dough to the sauce and it's not terrible. We go out for pizza because sometimes you just don't want to crank up the oven to 550F and bake your entire house (and for some 'industrial espionage' culling tips from the pros all over the pizza planet). Pizza Hacker came to our neighborhood and we have been converting friends and family to PzaHckr denizens whenever we don't have our own dough growing at home.

Pizza Hacker is top notch along side Tony's, Capo's, those NY Patsy's and Grimaldi's and better than John's, and we think superior to una pza napo. (Now that they're gone, why bother talking about them anyway). Hacker's sauces stands shoulder to shoulder with the best Nancy Silverton would make, harvested from Early Girl Tomatoes bringing this POW! The pepperoni on the Ohio has so much flavor, cups and miraculously doesn't issue an oil puddle you would find under an old Chevy with a leaking transmission. (They even shared the secret of their pep source). Tangy sauce and pepperoncini make a wondrous pizza. We've tried them all, lately we keep going back to Ohio.

Pizza Hacker likes to cook until their crust is stiff enough to support the toppings and get a fair amount of char on the crust. The dough tastes good, with a little yeast and some of that SF sour, but just a touch.

Beer choices rotate, usually an IPA, a saison or sour, a kolsch or something light on tap. Wine and sodas too.

Always love the Intermezzo salad. Reminds us of the old days getting lunch at the Owl and Monkey. Very fresh and full of colorful beans and roots, and well tossed. The Kale Caesar is great too.

Prices are fair, even pretty reasonable for San Francisco. What's to complain about? Communal tables shared with kids maybe, sometimes you have to wait, but turnover is pretty good. People who do not believe Pizza Hacker executes deliciously probably believe The Love Boat was the greatest show ever broadcast, IOW, they have little taste of substance and might be happier at "Yard of Pizza for One Dollar" strip mall chains. That's cool, they can go elsewhere so we can enjoy this good stuff.

Pizza Hacker, keep doing it like you mean it!
author: Jibber J.

description: Pizza was delicious and unique! Crust was a sourdough based and had just the right amount of salt and sauce.
author: A F.

description: Good food, nice environment. A little loud, acoustically. A family favorite.
author: John M.

description: Start by sharing the intermezzo salad - growing up in the north bay, it reminds me of the kind of salad my mother would make for us kids growing up - awesome hippied out salad.  Pizza highlights for me are the rocket man and just the simple margarita.  I've noticed that some reviewers complain about the crust but I think it's absolutely perfect and that they just don't really get it.  It's supposed to be a bit charred because it's baked at a high heat - it lends so much flavor to the thin crust along with the sprinkle of smoked salt.  I just wish I lived closer to Bernal.  Perfect night - pizzas at the hack and manhattans at the royal across the street.
author: scott P.

description:
In my head I know PizzaHacker is more of a 4-star spot, but I honestly can't stop thinking about going back, so I had to bump it up. They have very few pre-designed pizza options and they're all Italian style ... but if that's your jam, then PizzaHacker is a top SF spot. 

The only one I bother getting is the margherita pizza. The crust is this, but has good flavor. The sauce is nice and tart (and I think made in-house). And if you ask nicely, they'll put on the spicy diavolo sauce or calabrian chilies to suite your heat needs. Do yourself a favor and ask for calabrian chilies ... it makes my mouth water thinking how tasty they make the pizza with their heat and tartness.

Finally, a few good beer options to quench your thirst.
author: Akash K.

description: True original pizza guy, he is a good people and makes good pizza with great ingredients, margarita is what I enjoy, I had it many times it is always good.
author: Michael N.

description:
I love pizzahacker pizza. But their service is probably the worst in town. Let's be honest - there are tons of great places to go for pizza in SF. Supporting local restaurants is a great thing to do, so I really wanted pizzahacker to be my local pizza place. But ideals only go so far - the place is open on random days, and, when you try to place an order, as I did tonight, the person who picked up said "the restaurant is too busy" and when I tried to ask a question he hung up on me.

These restaurants (think Saru, etc.) that prioritize disrespecting their customers over a reasonable business model aren't worth our support. They are the reason that local restaurants so often fail - great product, terrible management, terrible service. You can bet that I'll be telling everyone I know to avoid this restaurant - why deal with their crap when Delfina is just as close?
author: Arul T.

description: I had high hopes ordering this on Grubhub... recieved Short Bridge! Tasted burnt and barely any mushroom sausage or their over exaggerated fresh house stretched mozzarella. Will not come back!
author: Clara L.

description:
Good but not quite great. I would go back for a return visit, but not go out of my way to do so. Good salad and good pizza; crust is much better than average, yet nothing quite stood out as being particularly memorable. 

But, it was all still good. It's just that when I evaluate pizza, I think about whether or not I'd want so-and-so's version on my last dying day as a hypothetical, and no, Pizzahacker's version doesn't make my list.
author: Maya B.

description: The worst!! Overrated! Never again! The only good thing was our server, they didn't have Diet Coke for hubby and he ran across the ways and bought one for him and didn't charge us!
author: Robertta M.

description:
I LOVE PIZZAHACKER! The more and more I think about it, the more I love it. I forgot to mention their amazing beer selection (sour beers!!!) and wine selection (lambrusco!) 

The pizza is perfect.
author: Carleen W.

description: Hands down favorite pizza in SF. Amazing quality - Rocket Man and Top Shelf Marg are both killer, and the Summer Fave when it's in season. I don't love to eat in because for some reason I feel rushed and awkward at their tables but we often do pickup OR, even better, upstairs with Extra Toppings comedy on Tuesday nights.
author: tura s.

description: Solid pizza, one of my favorites in the city! Good prices. Always friendly staff. I love the rocket man and add Spanish chorizo! Also really enjoy the table seating, casual and communal.
author: .Strapped ..

description: A unique take on thin crust pizza in the city. They use a sourdough for the pizza base which pairs very well with their thin crust style pizzas. The pizzas are crispy with just the right amount of chewiness and a slight tangy flavor that just works. I'm a fan of thin crust pizza so this place is high on my list of pizza places. The pizza selections are pretty simple, they have a handful of signature pizzas. I recommend the short bridge and the rocket man. The short bridge is a their take on a pepperoni sausage and mushroom, they of course use fancier toppings but it's the same idea. Very tasty and well balanced for sauce cheese and toppings. What really surprised me was the rocket man, typically I don't like egg or arugula on my pizza but this one worked. The rocket man has a fresh egg, arugula, garlic, lemon, and fresh mozzarella. The crispy chewy crust really works well with the flavors of lemon and garlic and the nuttiness of the arugula pairs well with the mozzarella and egg. I don't like to deviate from the typical pizza but this one was good. The staff are friendly and welcoming and the place is very casual. The pizza here is definitely worth a try
author: Peter P.

description: For nearly $20 a pizza, this left us completely unsatisfied and still famished. There's barely any meat or veggies on this super thin crust pizza which makes it hard to justify the price. Taste wise - meh. Underwhelming.
author: Julie L.

description:
If I can easily polish off an entire pizza pie by myself...
with equal parts relish, enthusiasm, & carnality...

You get 5 stars. 

Last night I finally had the privilege of trying The Pizza Hacker's pizza.  Jeff, aka, The Pizza Hacker, developed quite a devoted following after he custom made his own pizza oven from a weber grill, & started selling his amazing creations all over the city.  

For his enterprising qualities alone, you gotta give the guy mad props.

In a very Cinderella story kind of way, he now has a full on restaurant in bernal heights.

A very cool, urban, & casual restaurant in bernal heights.

It's simple.  There's a couple of salads, & about 6 pies to choose from.  Mitchell's ice cream for dessert.  Small batch wine & beer.

That's all folks.

And you know what?  That's more than enough.  When the pizza is this good & this strong, there's no need for ornamentation or distraction.  The star product speaks for itself, & more than holds its own.

We decided on "Get A Room."  Spanish chorizo, onion, their (absolutely delicious) house tomato sauce, olives, fresh parmesano reggiano...

It was dynamite.  

Crust?  House sourdough thin.  It was crisp throughout.  Excellent.

The hot sauce I added took it to an almost ethereal level.

We had wine.  Well, I did.  He had beer.

I think I could have happily eaten the whole 13" pie by myself if I had been alone.

But, I share.

It was a simple, perfect meal.

I read that Jeff is "just trying to make the best pizza in the world."

He's off to a good start.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
The Top Shelf Margherita is currently my ultimate cheat meal. I can polish an entire pizza, no problem in twelve minutes flat and even sneak in a bite or two of my husband's pizza if there is still anything left on his plate. AND if he's not in protective mode deflecting my fork/knife making its way over. (Yes, I sometimes eat my non-NY style pizzas with a fork/knife. What of it?!)

So we all know the parking situation in this neighborhood can get atrocious however we just discovered they have a curb side pick up option. (How am I just learning about this?!) You're connected to PH via your mobile and they send a notification to let you know to pull up. I guess in the meantime you can idle somewhere, wherever you can get away. Once you see their notification you pull up, hold up the yellow screen to the window with your order number et voila! You are on your way back home, delicious pizza in tow and you didn't even need to get out of your pajamas to retrieve it if you don't want to. How brilliant is that? But now that I know this, this is terrible news for my low carb dieting efforts.
author: Esther A.

description:
You know how people always start reviews off with, 'I really wanted to like it but...'
Well, I kind of straight up didn't want to like this place. 
Something about the name really digs at me.
But I came anyway and the pizza was unreasonably good. 
Too legit, if I do say so myself. 

Inside is all communal seating... everyone's personal hell. But it is a great place to come with a group of 6-8 because then you won't have to share a table with one of the families who brought their screaming children along to bang plates, cry, and mash chalk on their giant chalkboard wall. When we got here that description could be applied to every table in the joint... so apparently it's family friendly if you're into that sort of thing. 

I'm not.

But that pizza was sooo good. 

Thin crust, artisan toppings great combos, and they aren't jerk about adding our substituting stuff on their already put together pizza combos- in fact, it seemed pretty encouraged. 

They have a small but varied selection of beer and wine on tap and a few bottle offering as well. You'll notice salt, pepper, crushed red pepper flakes, and Calabrian hot chili pepper oil on all the tables. If you like spicy, def dig into the Calabrian pot- I sauced up my already perfect pizza with it and it was some next level sh*t. 

I got the upgraded margherita pizza and also added kalamata olives and like I said before, it was perfect. 

Our service was super chill and the vibe is super casual to the point where you might not be sure if you just order at the counter of if this is the sit down and get a menu type place (it's the latter). 

Despite my initial and inexplicable dislike of the restaurant name, my pizza was incredible and I can't wait to find myself back here again.
author: Candice G.

description: Pizza is soooo good and the staff is very nice. Came in around 9:30 on Sunday to meet my cousins who had already ordered and ate. They had ordered a short bridge and Ohio and we added one more of each. I thought the pizza was amazing, very flavorful. I didn't get our waiters name but he was very attentive and even grated fresh Parmesan for me. Even though it was close to closing they didn't rush us out and even gave us a one of the pizzas on the house. Will definitely be back!
author: Marissa M.

description:
PIZZAHACKER is...

...the most hipster pizza place of all the hipster places in the Mish.
...relatively calm ~6:30pm last Saturday.

...a mish mash of funky benches and brightly colored chairs.
...a wall doing double duty as a menu and chalk scribbling magnet for kiddies.

...a regular sized Intermezzo salad of organic greens and veggies nicely dressed in poppyseed dressing ($8).
...a short wait for a Hubby approved meaty Short Bridge pizza ($18) and a lighter Summer Fave pizza ($17).

...a debate re: if the crust was burned or not. (Spoiler alert! It was burned).
...an odd question from server. (After putting down $100 to cover the ~$40 check being asked "Do you need change?")

...a new addition to the "would definitely go back" list.
author: Amy C.

description:
Taste: Amazing
Service: no problems at all
Decor: comfortable, though I don't remember much
Price for quality: I don't THINK I paid?
Beers: gosh, I hope not...I had a bit too many

Sorry for the near useless review (I was three sheets to the wind when we stopped for victuals) but even in that state I knew this was some of the best pizza I've ever had, including 'za from NYC, Jersey Shore, Mystic, Chi-town and Bean Town... and Rome. Pizza.
author: Dave H.

description:
Really good pizza! A bit pricey but you can tell the ingredients are fresh and worth it. The margherita and Yo Vinny were our favorites. The kale Cesar salad was great too. 

I placed an order for delivery and was impressed that they called to let me know my order was ready but the delivery service hadn't picked it up yet which I found was thoughtful.

The leftover pizza reheated very well in a toaster oven the next day.
author: Megan P.

description:
Please do not eat here! People of Sf need to stand up against these restaurants that over charge for a product that isn't a good portion size. I paid $19 for a margarita pizza that is 12"..... That's like a personal pizza any where else. Should get a 19-22" pie for $20. This business rips customers off with some BS pizza and high prices. Too many places in SF that claim some sort of quality standard and just take an arm and a leg from good working people.

This is the reason rent is high in SF and being gentrified.

I like your crust but dude, this isn't the ski resort or an NBA game.....
author: Eli B.

description:
First of, the address says Bernal Heights, but it's actually Mission street, right opposite the Freakin Chicken place.

Parking is a NIGHTMARE. BUT, once you step in, you forget all that pain and irritation of driving around four or five times, and begin to soak in everything about this place.

The pizzas are GOOOOOOD! The table hosts are so sweet and friendly and kind and patient!

The place is kid friendly. Seriously kid friendly! 

Be careful of the benches if you're going with some elderly.

Rocket man pizza - SO good. The egg in the center is to die for, nice and runny! The arugula is another bonus.

The Margarita pizza - good, tasty, fresh sauce. 

I loved that they have hot pepper paste on the table! I loved the corner shelf with bottles of canned tomato and canned peppers! Visual treat!! 

I would say the pizza base is more like thin crust. 

The Mitchell's ice cream as finale is worth it!

The Intermezzo salad is good too!

Overall experience - delightful.
author: Me Iz S.

description:
Happened to only stumble across this place on our way to happy hour at Ichi Ni. So glad we came in because the PIZZA WAS FREAKIN DELICIOUS. And best of all, no wait or crowds! Yay for being in the Bernal Heights area :)

Service is extremely nice and attentive, seating is all open so it kind of gives it a park or family vibe. :)

The Rocket Man for $15 was simply divine. (Mozz, farm egg, arugula, chili, lemon juice, garlic, parmigiano & garlic). EVERYTHING was balanced out so well. Thin crust so you don't feel like utter crap after eating it.

YUM! Will return!
author: Emily C.

description:
Been wanting to go here. Been passing by it via bus or in a car. Y'know how parking is around here... Well, as luck would have it, there was a parking spot across the street on Thursday night around 7 p.m.  Finally, tried this place!

Food = great. 

Salad Intermezzo (little gems, chicories, butter lettuce, carrot, cucumber, chickpeas, farm egg, radish with poppy seed dressing) = delicious.  What a refreshing salad. Granted, I'd skip the chickpeas next time, as I'm not a big fan of it. Definitely glad I asked about the sizing, because the medium was more than enough for the two of us. Medium, $7.36  (Gigante $13.79 and it's not a lie! It would probably feed 3-4!)

Marinara (dry-farmed early girl tomatoes, garlic, oregano, arbequina olive oil, alderwood smoked salt, grana padano) = thin crust, great sauce, light on the cheese. $11.95

Yo Vinny! (marinated onions, Mama Lil's pickled goat horn peppers, house-made hot italian sauce, tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, grana padano) = thin crust with a great combination of sweet, salty, and tangy. Excellent sausage. $16.55 

Everything appears to be locally sourced, and they even offer Mitchell's ice cream for dessert. 

Soft drinks = we had a coca cola and ginger ale (ginger ale was very light and reminded me of sparking apple more than ginger) $2.76 x2

Service = friendly! 

Decor = 4-tops, bench seating and chairs. But you can share the tables for 6-8 people, or just be friendly with your dining neighbors.  Gotta love the chalkboard for waitlist and their menu. 

Yes, it gets noisy in here. And they will play loud music, too. You've been warned.

Prices = moderate. Dinner for two came out to $45.00 with leftovers. 

Hours are Tuesday to Sunday 5 pm to 10 pm. Another dinner only place!
author: Fannie S.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while - ever since I heard about the Weber grill being hacked into a pizza oven. Sadly, they no longer use the hacked oven, but a 'regular' pizza oven now. 

I came with a group and tried 5 or 6 pizzas along with a couple salads. All of the food was good as they used fresh ingredients in tasty combinations. The pizza crust is very flatbread like - thin and crispy with not a lot of chew. I'd say the downside to the pizzas is that the thin crust sometimes got soggy if there were too many wet ingredients on the pie.
author: Judy C.

description:
This is my favorite pizza in the city! The dough is amazing and all the flavors are to die for. 
I became a fan back when the Hacker was making pizzas on his rigged Weber grill on Folsom St and then in a bar off Divisadero. The atmosphere is very chill and you can reserve a room upstairs for parties.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
One of my favorite food groups with a twist.

We started our dinner with the Intermezzo salad. The salad contained large leafy greens and a strong poppyseed dressing. I liked the idea of little gems and farm eggs but those were hard to find. 

Next we had the Crowd Pleaser which I was really excited about because of the prosciutto! When the pizza finally came, there was only prosciutto on one half of the pizza... We were slightly confused. After telling the waitress, they kindly put more prosciutto on the other half of the round! whoot! But sadly that was the only good part of the pizza. The bottom was mildly burnt and the greens made the entire bite taste completely bitter. Maybe we should've said something? But I assumed this is what the crowd is asking for. Can't complain about what we are being pleased with! 

Lastly we had the Heavy Nettle. I just wanted the lamb meatballs and the stracciatella (since I thought that it only came in an ice cream form). This time, the pizza was baked perfectly and the meatballs and other ingredients were a beautiful compliment to the thinly baked dough. I was super happy with this one.

PizzaHacker are for the right minded people that are evolving from the ordinary combo pizza.
author: Linda K.

description:
Great variety of draft beer offerings (concise but robust enough to cater to most) 
Redhen Saison is a winner! 
Pitchers of beer are offered 
A great assortment of pizzas 
Caesar salad croutons were hard as rocks (they thankfully comped it when we gave them feedback) 
Reasonably priced for a whole pie 

Crust had a great flavor and crisp throughout 
Toppings were fresh and stood out 
Tomato sauce was lush, vibrant and flavorful 

Overall Thoughts

Delicious place to grab a slice with friends
author: Eddie W.

description:
We got there right at opening on Saturday, with kids.  Meet by a slightly friendly, slightly disinterested Italian waiter (felt like was in Italy! Ha). The beer menu and pizza menu are basic, but butt the necessities.  We ordered 3 pizzas to start and added 2 more add we ate.  Pretty quick, and tasty. 

At the start of the evening, almost every table was a family with kids (long benches for tables), and we were quite happy it was kid friendly. 

Will come again
author: tom S.

description:
I'm not really a pizza person.. so I'd say this was pretty good? They make small thin-crust pizzas with interesting toppings. There are usually ~7-8 different beers and a handful of wines by the glass offered. The ambience is super casual - they just have a large space with a few benches + tables, and you seat yourself anywhere.

1) Rocket man with added chorizo - totally got this for the egg on top. I love anything plus egg on top. And then there was also some arugula and lemon juice.
2) Short bridge - sausage, sorpressata, and prosciutto (possibly?) with mushrooms and some other stuff, definitely for the meat eater!
(You can go on their website for the full description of each pizza.)

For dessert though, I got a scoop of Mitchells' chocolate ice cream with olive oil and sea salt YUMM!! I know it sounds a tad weird initially, but the flavors complement each other really well, as long as you don't overdo the olive oil. I recently discovered this combination at a different location and have been obsessed ever since.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Oh, how I love pizza! We had a large group and luckily they were able to accommodate us pretty quickly considering it was a Saturday night. We ordered 5 pizzas for about 10 of us to share and that got us pretty satisfied. We had:

- Margherita: it was good, but I'm more of a non-vegetarian type of eater

- Yo Vinny!: This was is pretty much like a combo pizza and it was good as well. Nothing super amazing though

- Rocket Man: This one was my favorite. It had argugla, pandano (some kind of really thin meat), lemon and a sunny side up egg. I love the combination of the lemon, arugula, and pandano. the only thing that sucks is that it's really hard to split the egg because it's just on once slice of the pizza.

Overall, it was good pizza. The pizzas are kind of thin though so they're not super filling unless you order more than your usual (unless that's just me). And they have a cool artsy atmosphere.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Pizza nirvana.  Margherita is the basic and the best. Prices reasonable for the quality and quantity.  Martha was amazing.  Took the time to stop and talk pizza hacker lore and history with us.
author: Bob B.

description:
Yup, 5 stars.  I live around the corner, come here way too much, and it's consistently great.  The Kale Caesar salad is so much better than a kale salad has any right to be, and the Yo Vinny and the Short Bridge pizzas are my faves.  Pro-tip: get the Margherita with pickled goat-horn peppers.  

Also usually a small but very solid beer and wine selection.  Great place to go with friends, but be aware that it's family-friendly and noisy.
author: Liz B.

description: A very disappointing burnt crust. Twice in a row. I'm thinking I ain't going back. :(
author: Tracy Y.

description: Great place for family and friends. The atmosphere is crazy and the walls are chalkboard to write on. The owner is usually in and loves to tell his story of how he started by creating an oven and riding around on his bike selling pizza. Delicious pizza and vegan friendly!
author: AnnaClaire M.

description: Seriously, how is pizza hacker only 4 stars??  Best pizza west of the Mississippi.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Worst experience ever last night... Several employees started giving me the wrong kinda attitude, when it could easily have been avoided! Did they forget about Yelp?
author: Torfin S.

description:
I have lived in New York and visited Milan and had pizzas all over the world.... so take this with a grain of salt when i say it.

Pizzahacker is my favorite pizza on the planet.

Pick up an XX-L Intermezzo salad and a Rocket man for an amazing dinner that easily feeds two.

They have occasional pop-ups that you should visit too.
author: Jay Z.

description: The pizza is good -- excellent crust. Some come with a farm egg! That said -- we waited for ONE HOUR for our pizza last night. ONE HOUR. The place was packed and the music was SO LOUD that we had to sit there and yell at one another for ONE HOUR before we got our pizza. By the time it arrived, we were so hungry, we gobbled it up in 10 minutes and then got the hell out. So. . .more ovens or something? What is your solution, Pizza Hacker? Something because waiting ONE HOUR is just too long. . .
author: Lorelei L.

description:
Had dinner here with friends on Saturday night.
They were busy ,but  we were seated right away.

The server was friendly, and the food came surprisingly fast.
We all LOVED the pizza. 
This is definitely a favorite place of mine.

The owner was there and remembered us from a previous visit, (although it been awhile.)
Very personable guy and he's running a great restaurant.

We will definitely be back more frequently!
author: Amanda G.

description: Pizza is often burnt around the edge. This time, it was bad enough to post a comment on Yelp. It was a takeout so I didn't ask for a new one.
author: D M.

description:
A popup expands into a retail space in Bernal Heights.  Lots of young families with little babies were eating there, early in the evening. Pretty family friendly.


Fast online ordering and pickup system.

Picks:
Short Bridge Pizza ($17.47) Fra'mani Sopressata, House-made Italian Sausage, Mushrooms, Bianco/DiNapoli Tomato sauce, Fresh House-Stretched Mozz, Dried Oregano, Grana Padano was the better of the 2 pizzas. Lots of meat and bold flavors on this one. 

Top Shelf Margherita Pizza ($15.63) Dry-Farmed Early Girl Tomato Sauce, Fresh Mozzarella, Basil, Bariani Olive Oil, Smoked Salt, Grana Padano  was not as top shelf as advertised.  Could have used better quality cheese. Crust was very thin, lots of blister marks, hint of salt.
author: Ellen H.

description: The best pizza in the locale, in my opinion probably the best in San Francisco. That's it....enjoy
author: Stephen M.

description: This place has awesome thin crust pizza. I can't believe it took me this long to finally set foot in this joint. There's also vegan options as well! The pizza comes out piping hot and tastes the best that way. If you plan on ordering more than one, ask the waiter to hold off on your next pizza until you're almost done with your first. The only thing that I didn't see in the tables was Parmesan cheese but there was hot chili to top off your pie.
author: W A.

description: Pizzahacker is my go-to for going-out-for-pizza. I highly recommend dinning in, if only for the high ceilings and chalk wall. (I've never ordered takeout from here.) The kale salad + Get A Room + beer combo is all my desires packed in one meal. The restaurant is always busy, but I've never had to wait more than ~10 minutes to get a table or bar seat.
author: Whitney H.

description: Best pizza joint in town!!! Salads are on point. Have NEVER been disappointed. Service is prompt, waiters are cool, atmosphere is alive!
author: Nicholas B.

description:
After four straight days of eating hot & sour soup because I had a cold, all I wanted to do was wrap my mouth around something with texture, crunch, and a nice, toothsome chew. Something that will hit that [sweet] spot and make me groan with incredible satisfaction. You know, pizza. A piping hot slice of cheeselicious pizza at 3 am always hits the spot right?

Soft opening 3 weeks ago, Pizza Hacker's brick and mortar (formerly Incas) finally came into fruition after years at Dolores Park and popping up at Vinyl Coffee & Wine Bar baking pizza from a makeshift pizza oven using a Weber Grill. How cool is that?

I never got to try their pizza but since Pizza Hacker's new spot is just several minutes away from me, now was my chance. 

The chalkboard menu is small with just one salad and five pizza options: http://bit.ly/1fi0rvL. I don't mind small menus since it allows the chef(s) to select the best seasonal ingredients and perfect the few dishes they offer well.

All pizzas are a very reasonable $15 which includes tax. They also have one red and one white wine  ($8/glass, $30/bottle), 4 beers ($5/glass, $27 pitcher), and sodas ($3). CC's accepted.

Pizza Hacker is family friendly since there's picnic tables (communal seating); right to be exact and a chalk board for kids to scribble on while they await their pie: http://bit.ly/1dB8oJl. If you find yourself having to wait for a table, hit up Rock Bar (owned by Front Porch) down the block for some drinks: http://bit.ly/1avgubW. 

The staff is incredibly friendly. It was our waiter's first day and he did a great job and promptly taking and delivering our order. 

I'm four reviews behind on my pizza reviews but Pizza Hacker is a step below Delfina's for me. My top five picks are still Una Pizza Napolatana, Pizzetta 211, Baonecci, Tony's and A16 (pending review).

Maybe I choose the wrong pizza but I felt the Intermezzo Salad ($8) outshined my pizza: http://bit.ly/1mCiTBD. The salad was ginormous and was enough to feed 4-5 people. All the ingredients were uber fresh and dressed in a deliciously savory and nicely tangy poppy seed dressing. I loved the garbanzo and kidney beans for a meaty bite. Definitely one of the best salads I've had!

For my pizza, I decided to go with the Crowd Pleaser w/ Radicchio, mission figs, bleu cheese, balsamic, fresh mozzarella & rosemary ($15) since it got rave reviews from their previous Yelp reviews: http://bit.ly/19SdlCF. Plus, I'm a sucker for savory and sweet pairings. Sometimes less is more and which this was the case with the crowd pleaser as it was overwhelmed with radicchio and balsamic vinegar making the pizza too bitter and sour for my liking. The middle was immediately soggy as a result too. 

Being the carniwhore that he is, Mr. NSS for the Yo Vinny: Marinated onions, goat horn peppers, 4505 hot Italian sausage, tomato sauce & fresh mozzarella ($15): http://bit.ly/1e1fJGw which I favored over the Crowd Pleaser. Everything was well balanced with a good amount of oooeeey goooey cheese and a spicy porkiness from the sausage. 

Now the reason why I can't rank Pizza Hacker in my top 5s is because of the crust which truly is a matter of preference. What makes Pizza Hacker's crust unique is it's sprinkled with smoked sea salt for that extra bite of flavor. However, I felt the crust was too carb heavy for me as I prefer a more light and crackly, thin crust.  Also I couldn't get over the immediate sogginess with the Crowd Pleaser. 

Next time, I'm going with the Rocket Man which is topped with a farm egg. Maybe that will change my mind. Nothing quite gets me going like the sight of oozing yolk porn....
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I can usually tell if I'll like a pizza immediately base solely on it's appearance. So superficial. I know. This time, with Pizza Hacker, I was wrong...

I've been drooling over Pizza Hacker food pics since they were merely a pop up. I was ecstatic when they opened up a store front in Bernal a couple months back. I finally made my way over there and was disappointed by the pizza; however, the value / price is amazing. I would return just because I feel like I ordered the wrong thing....

Tips:
- They don't do 2 flavors on one pie. You can modify ingredients (for a cost).
- One pie is 6 slices, can serve 2 people who aren't super hungry because the crust is decently thick for thin crust.

* ROCKET MAN ($15.63) - 3 STARS:
Arugula, Garlic, Fresh Mozzarella, Farm egg, lemon juice, chili paste. (+Sausage). The crust is thin but thick enough to have a nice and chewy bite, but I felt that there wasn't enough toppings and flavor to balance it out. It was a bit flavorless, despite it being doused generously with oil and roughly cut garlic. The most disappointing thing was that the egg was completely hard and overcooked. 

* CABERNET SAUVIGNON ($19.31) -  3 STARS:
Y+B - Cabernet Sauvignon - Lodi - 2011. Not complaining for a half carafe this seems like a great deal!

* MADRE CHOCOLATE - Not available anymore
No longer being sold here =( They only have shave ice for dessert.
author: Jess C.

description: We stopped in for the Tues. night free comedy show on the 2nd floor (you get a discount on the pizza if you RSVP, but then we completely forgot to tell the cashier so didn't get our discount lol). As far as thin crust, wood-fired pizzas go, Pizza Hacker is the best in SF, really. We've eaten several times at Pizzetta 211, Fiorella's and Mozzaria (Off the Grid) but PH is by far our favorite. We're guessing the dough is lightly soaked in sea salt maybe? Anyhoo, it's absolutely delicious with just the right slighly chewy inside crispy outside texture. My favorite is the North Bridge (sausage, mushrooms). Some unique flavors, combinations. True the pies were not cheap, but it was less expensive/on par with the other places with wood-fired ovens. Each pie is big enough for two people with moderate appetites.
author: Kate A.

description:
Overpriced!!! Called in ahead of time to place order (for pick up). The person on the other line said they were too busy to take orders. Later she changed her mind and took my order. 

I was charged for $3.00 per topping.  The toppings were painted on. Hardly any sausage or pepperoni on one of the pies, and hardly any chorizo on the other. I was charged $40.00 for two pizzas, which were 13". I could have gotten way better service, more food, and better toppings at a chain for the same price including tip!

I was not quoted the cost over the phone. I was told to pick up the pizza in 30 minutes because it was busy... I arrived 30 minutes later (on the dot) and the pizza was sitting on top of the oven. It was lukewarm at best. 

Don't eat here if u plan to take ur food home. For $40.00 you can bake a better pizza yourself using great ingredients.

I was dissatisfied yet I still tipped. I tipped not because the server made it a point to tell me I should choose the tip amount on the app.  I tipped because I know how hard it is for the folks in the service industry to make a decent wage.  The tip was for the cooks who made the meal. 

The restaurant owner can take a hike.  The greed in charging way too much because it's San Francisco disgusts me. DON'T EAT HERE UNLESS YOU WANT TO OVERPAY. 

I've spent between $10.00 for a meal and up to $580.00 for only myself. Each restaurant has its charm, just not this one. 

- Written by a Yelper who enjoys dining
author: Luis S.

description: The pizza was good The downside for me here was the selection. everything being one size and only a few options is not ideal.
author: David S.

description:
This is actually my second visit.  The first time was MUCH better.
This time, we were 8 people so we booked ahead but still had to wait 10 minutes when we got there... and the food, while good, was not great. I'm giving an extra star on previous merits, because I think it may have been an off night.

Noise can be a serious issue here, so plan for that.

Yo Vinnie pizza was the crowd favorite.

The kalamata olives are just too much of a statement on whichever pie has them... kinda ruined it for most people in our party. (kids be warned! you will not like the 'Get a Room' pizza!)

The top shelf marg was good, but not as good as I remembered from last year.

The place is a block from my family's house, so I'll be back.

Dinner for 8 for $100 before tip is a great, easy, evening out!  And kids can use chalk on the walls!
author: Josh K.

description: Nice crispy, chewy crust, with a complex flavor. Intermezzo salad is a great veggie salad! Shared tables remind me a bit of elementary school, but as an adult I enjoy them.
author: Jay G.

description: Love this chill spot for a delicious salad, pizza, and glass of wine. You'll share bench seating with other groups and enjoy cheesy deliciousness and neighborhood camaraderie. The staff is super chill and friendly. There are often a lot of families with kids (super kid friendly!). And for dessert, you can enjoy Mitchell's chocolate ice cream with sea salt and olive oil.
author: Tasha D.

description:
This restaurant is the reason I come to San Francisco. This hidden gem has the most gosh darn ridiculously delicious food. As I bite into the famous marg pizza my taste buds rejoice as the taste of the sourdough crust and in house marinara makes me feel the sea breeze against my supple cheeks. I have two words for you pizza hacker. Thank you. Oh and the brunette sever is a mega babe and literally converted me to lesbianism the moment I laid eyes on her. Ten out of ten would recommend.

Update still just as dank. #danktank  don't listen to the pretentious dbags leaving crap reviews this place is awesome.
author: Emily B.

description:
Goood pizza HORRIBLE service. Cool atmosphere & great beer & wine selection! 
We had to wait a little hit in a week night, no biggie. What is a biggie is when you take over 15 mins to bring out drinks & we have to ask a 2nd time. No doubt in our mind, our sever was stoned... Fine, but do it in your own time & do t forget our beers... Sorry dude!
Our table ordered the kale salad which was decent & we order 4 pizzas. We only got 3 :( when we inquired a long time after we had placed the order we were told that is was made but they could never find the ticket so they gave it away! :(:(:(
The pizzas we did get were thin crust & wonderfully crispy. If you're pretty hungry you can probably finish the whole pizza & be quite full.
For dessert they have Mitchell's ice cream! We didn't order that... Not sure if we would have gotten it anyway :/
My husband & I have also ordered take out from them. It came in a reasonable amount of time & order was accurate! The crust was just not as great as in the restaurant (obviously) but we actually got everything we ordered... Hmm
author: Ashley G.

description:
Our first time to Pizza Hacker and it was Ok. The space is like an indoor picnic setting with picnic-style tables that are communal. That's fine. 

The pizza selection is limited but definitely interesting. It would appear that most are regular choices with a couple that might change more often. The pizza flavor was good but it was very messy as the topping ran all over. That's not too big of an issue of you don't mind eating with a fork and knife, but it also made the crust soggy in the middle. I definitely do not like soggy crust. My crust needs to be crispy. 

The last demerit, of you will, was the very indifferent service.  You're in the service industry, so show some enthusiasm about helping customers. 

With all of the great pizza places in SF, I'm not sure I'd go back.
author: Scott L.

description:
First impressions - excellent-- I'll return for sure,

Masterful crust, local freshest sourced ingredients, who could ask for more! Big tantalizing Menu. Need I say more. 

We met the big guy Jeff and talked shop- he's really got it goin on.
author: Craig B.

description: One of the best in SF. No fancy decor, just some damn good pizza. If you're looking for a fine dining experience, go elsewhere, if you want a perfect slice of pizza and a relaxed vibe, go here.
author: Ryen M.

description:
This place is kind of out of the way for lots of people so I'm so glad that postmates exists. I love to get food delivered when I'm lazy and don't want to leave my apartment. 

Pizzahacker is one of those places that suggests using postmates which is kind of cool (offer it for less delivery cost please!). When I got the pizza (top shelf marg), it was already a little cold which made me sad, but I should have put it into the oven to warm it up a bit, but it was good regardless. I definitely had it a couple days later and it was good. The margarita pizza was traditional and definitely so good. 

I also got the intermezzo salad (which was supposed to be similar to the salad from this great place in Berkeley). It wasn't the same salad since there wasn't as much of it, but it was pretty similar. The items were very similar, but I wished for more toppings since that's what I remembered from those salads. 

Overall, get the pizza and get the salad and you won't really regret it. 

Protip: the pizza is good. Definitely get the pizza.
author: Nina Y.

description:
I'm a New York City transplant and Pizza Hacker makes some of the only pizza in all of San Francisco that meets my standards. The pizzas are delicious -- great sauce, crust, toppings, etc. -- and the salads are a really good too. (I'm a big fan of the kale caesar.)

Expect to wait a while for a table if you get there during peak dinner hours, but it's worth it. The only downside of this place is that it gets a little loud when it's busy -- but for pizza this good, it's worth a little noise.
author: Elsa M.

description:
I want to preface by saying that I'm not much of a pizza guy. I know that's sacrilege - everybody loves pizza, right? - but it's not my junk food of choice. Too many carbs. I hate the post-greasy-pizza nausea that follows. Thanks for shaking my disbelief, Pizzahacker. 

My fiancee and I are food snobs in our own right. She's really into freshness and flavor, and I'm obsessed with food pairings (i.e. Cilantro+Avocado+Lime). We ordered three pizzas - the Yo Vinny!, "Top Shelf" Margherita, and the Rocket Man - and, goodness gracious, it was awesome. There's a lot of good food in the Bay Area but there's something really special about this place. Everything tastes homemade and in the good way. The really good way. Behind us were shelves of onions, peppers, and olives that they were marinating/pickling.. They make the cheese fresh every two days. The chorizo (which is the best I've ever had) is imported from Spain. There's a lot of shortcuts you can take in food preparation, for both convenience and cost, and Pizzahacker totally disregards that and serves you handcrafted love. 

Ryan, our server, was the man. Not only was he super friendly and helpful, he was a blast to talk to and he genuinely wanted us to try how good his restaurant's pizza was. Here are Ryan's recommendations and they will blow your mind: 1) Get the "Yo Vinny!" with Spanish chorizo and use the fresh chili sauce at the table. 2) Get the "Rocket Man" with an extra farm egg. You take the pizza squares around the perimeter and dip it into the runny yolk and then for a brief moment you witness eternity.
author: Roman W.

description:
I gave this place two shots and both times I was disappointed. Personally I don't understand the hype. It bothered me that the crust was very well done, basically burned, both times, and for how much they charge I was expecting better tasting pizza. I've experienced better pizza. I'm writing this review to hopefully balance out the stars a bit to more accurately reflect the establishment as I saw it. 

Tip: Check your pizza to make sure their crust is up to your liking and don't feel bad about sending it back, per the owner's orders. Personally I think that should be the wait staff's job - to check and make sure the pizza isn't burned - but the owner thinks it's your job (the customers), according to a note he wrote me. And if you don't like your pizza, email the owner. He wants to know.
author: Dee K.

description:
This is my favorite pizza place in the city right now.  The top shelf margarita is paradise on a plate.  The ingredients are just so fresh, the sauce is always perfectly balanced, and the crust simply can't be beat.  You can really feel that the focus is on craftsmanship and getting the basics exactly right.

We love that PizzaHacker is all about pizza over fancy decor, pretensions, novelty, or gratuitously attentive service people.  It's just amazing (euro-style) pizza, excellent beer, and a comfortable casual environment.

One word of caution is that PizzaHacker pizza is best served and eaten hot and fresh out of the oven.  We find that because it's thin crust, it doesn't travel particularly well.  It tends to cool down and harden faster than traditional american style pizza.  Therefore, we usually save PizzaHacker pizza for a night out rather than a night in.
author: Moira M.

description:
As you pass through the unassuming entrance, you enter an open room laid out as though in a school playground, with metal picnic tables and long benches on each side and an aisle in the middle. There's a chalkboard wall to the left which is another nod to the nostalgia of school effect before white boards were invented.  The menu is written up there, semi permanently with seasonal specialities which usually puts a twist on the classics such as the Margherita.

The open kitchen is at the far end, with a large pizza oven.  It's not one of those brick ovens or the large ovens with each brick hand laid from Italy-nothing fancy.  It's an industrial size one that I've seen at other places like Goia or Arinell's.  I'm not perturbed by the sight.  I'm not a pizza purist like the Una Pizza Napoletana's owner - I accept that variations in pizza cooking styles are as variable as each handcrafted pie.  They're good when they're honestly made, with precision, and love.

My favorite is the Yo Vinny.  The pickled horn peppers and the marinated onions forms a great kinship of sweet and spicy, with the slight subtle sting of the hot Italian sausage.  The tomato sauce, made from organic, heirloom tomatoes are usually Early Girl tomatoes of which the sweetness marries well with the fresh mozzarella.  

A close second is the Short Bridge, a second cousin of the Yo Vinny, with Fra'mani Sopressata, mushrooms, dried oregano, and grana padano.  I was a little skeptical of the oregano which didn't seem to belong on the pie but it lent an herbaceous nuance to the pie that I imagine what a nana's tomato sauce would taste like.  

The pies come out quickly, blistered and slighted charred, leopard skinned, with small hills and valleys.  A perfectly symmetrical pie, a la Domino's or Pizza hut style it is not.  The crust maintains its crisp crackle but eat it quickly as it doesn't last long under the weight of the voluminous toppings.  I'm usually a two slicer myself, but faced with such a beauty, I happily inhale half of the pie.  Thank goodness it's sooo thin!

A jar of calabrian peppers is at each table, available at Bi-Rite according to the waitress, an indulgence that is in accordance to their religion that is to create the perfect pie but a surprise when you consider the price of such pie.  For such quality ingredients and product, the prices are definitely a bargain for the Bay area, heck, for any area.
author: Betty T.

description: i got the special margarita.  it was decent.  but in my opinion, too much sauce and not enough basil.
author: Cin D.

description:
If you have kids, this is an amazing place. If you don't, it's still pretty epic, though be weary of the 5pm crowd (like me) with kids. If you come after 6pm, you are golden. 

Good beer selection, awesome pizza, perfect salads and chalk for the kids! I love how fast the service is and how attentive the staff is. With two families -- 4 adults and 5 kids between us -- we were in and out in under an hour. Bellies were full, kids, moms and dads were all happy. That's a win in my book.
author: carli m.

description:
Yum pizza! We had the rocket man :)
The egg was A great addition and the ambiance is super chill :) 
Beers are tasty and service is good.
author: Raquel M.

description:
Been here 11 years and that (magherita) was the best pizza I've had in San Francisco.

Also got some chocolate ice cream, which was lovely.
author: Dunstan O.

description:
Living nearby I was happy to see a new pizza place emerge from a building that has held a bank, Rock Soup, and a Peruvian restaurant.  Having heard of the FranenWeber pop ups, but me not wanting to be out and about after midnight, I was happy to see a brick and mortar for pizza.  Let's face it, if you know this area there is not much decent pizza nearby.  One may be fine for kids, and the other was very good a dozen + years ago, pizza pickings are slim.

I've tried just about every pizza offered, but usually fall back to my standard Top Shelf Margherita or Yo Vinny, my favorite being the Yo Vinny.  It is something about those marinated peppers.  I always add a hefty dose of the chili paste.  Toppings may be sparse, but that is the nature of a good pizza.  I don't want tons of cheese or toppings; I want quality ingredients bringing everything together.  That's what you get at PizzaHacker.  Thin crust, properly charred in an electric oven that reads 666 degrees.

An Intermezzo salad is available with poppy seed dressing, but ask for croutons.   Beer and wine are available, but I usually opt for water.  Some pizzas are added as toppings come into season.

Not much in atmosphere, as tables consist of park tables and benches with chairs scattered.  Children will have great fun with one wall being a chalkboard, while parents enjoy their meal.
author: Michael M.

description:
Bomb dot com, yo.  Some of the best pizza I've had in the city.

The Short Bridge is my new favorite pizza:  Fra'mani Sopressata, House-made Italian Sausage, Mushrooms, Bianco/DiNapoli Tomato sauce, Fresh House-Stretched Mozz, Dried Oregano, & Grana Padano. It is f'in exquisite.  I had the leftover slices for days and they seemed to just get better.  

My friend had the Margherita and he was quite satisfied.  

Can't wait to return and just hope they don't get too busy because this place is legit!
author: Saminda W.

description: Some of their pizzas are really good while others are mediocre. The mezzanine salad is pretty good too.
author: Priyanka S.

description:
Came here for the first time, made the mistake of ordering before grabbing a seat - can't do that apparently. The walls are chalkboards so you can write on them if you like; the kid sitting next to me was going at it, doing math problems and everything.

Solid pizza joint, did take a bit of time to come out but we got the amazing intermezzo salad to get us through the wait. Super bummed that the top shelf margherita was out so we settled for the regular margherita and the yo vinny - both were fantastic. Two pizzas and a medium salad was enough to fill 3 people.
author: Ryan L.

description: !Worth the hype! Thin crust pizza with tasty toppings. It is very casual and they have these benches which makes it easy to go with kids. They have their house wine which they keep rotating. I liked the wine too. The popular pizza is Short Bridge but we tried almost all of the pies and you cannot really go wrong! 5 stars*
author: Merve A.

description: Awesome pizza! It is a hidden gem in the mission district with an unassuming store front but boy is the food good. Salad to get is the kale Cesar! The special pizzas are usually very good. We ordered the brussel sprout pizza and it was outstanding.
author: Sam C.

description:
Legit thin crust; crunchier than your usual Neapolitan 'za when it cools off; perfect sauce-to-dough ratio; not salty or soggy; smoke salt and good olive oil is a nice touch; and no wait (per Sunday night observation)... I'm convinced this is going to be my staple pizza spot! 

We ordered Top Shelf and Short Bridge. Mind you if you want super cheesy, thick pizza packed with toppings, this is not your pick. The mozzarella was indeed on the lighter side on our Top Shelf Marge, but I'm sold with the dough and the combination.

Ah, and don't forget the Mitchell's Chocolate ice cream, topped with olive oil drizzles and smoke salt... Pleasantly surprised by the boosted olive oil aroma. Very intricate sweet and savory flavors!
author: Ida L.

description:
I've been hearing a lot about PizzaHacker from friends and was afraid to visit, imagining long lines like at every good pizza place in SF. But when I arrived on a Thursday evening for dinner we practically had our pick of tables. The place was only half full.

We ordered the top shelf 'marg' and the heavy nettle pizzas. The top shelf 'marg' was absolutely amazing! I'm not sure how they do it but the combination of melted cheese and tomato created this creamy mouthfeel and wonderfully satisfying flavor. I took a bit and immediately thought this is what comfort food is all about. Looks and sounds really simple but they've managed to elevate it to something else - doesn't even deserve to be in the same category as standard margherita pizzas. The heavy nettle pizza was good but in my mind not as amazing as the top shelf 'marg'.

Both pizzas were big for personal pizzas. Ideally 2 pizzas could be shared between 3 people.

Service was good but inattentive. We had to wait and really put effort into getting their attention when we wanted to leave.

*** TIP: Don't sit in the corner

$47 for two pizzas and a beer including tax and tip.

Pretty happy with how the evening turned out especially as when we cycled home there were the usual hordes waiting outside Beretta for a table. The pizza at PizzaHacker is at least as good and there's no wait at all. I can live with the trade-off in cool and cocktails to get my food right away.

*** NOTE: if you pay by credit card the total shown on Square includes tax and if you auto calculate tip it will be calculated on that total - if that matters to you 18% on the total is around 20% on the food only.
author: Jean K.

description: This is some of the best pizza I've ever had in my life, and I grew up in Philly and just moved from New York. The arugala one is super garlic-y and amazing.
author: Jason S.

description:
Top Shelf Margherita
(Dry-Farmed Early Girl Tomato Sauce, Fresh House Stretched Mozzarella, Basil (only 20/day).

Pretty good.  The crust is pretty buttery and has a nice touch of salt.  The tomato sauce is pretty tasty and the pizza is pretty creamy/cheesy.

Pizza Puttanesca 
Tomato Sauce, Garlic, Calabrian Chili Paste, Kalamata Olives, Capers, Local SF Anchovies 

As with any pizza with olives, capers, and anchovies, it is salty.  I like the spiciness of due to the chili paste but overall, it was too salty.
author: Heejin L.

description: Best thin crust pizza in the city! I would argue best pizza in the city period. Great ambience. The service is awesome. You can also create your own pizza with their wonderful selection of toppings; you are not limited to the selections on the menus. I would personally recommend the Yo Vinny with chorizo and the Rocket Man.
author: Garland U.

description:
Unbelievable pizza

Got the magarita, spicy sausage and salami

All very very good. 

Great base and toppings. Authentic italian style pizza
author: Scott L.

description:
2.5 stars

I had a high hope for this place after reading raving yelp reviews and pictures of beautiful Neapolitan style pizza with perfectly charred edges.  Unfortunately, it was quite a disappointing experience to dine here.  

We ordered a Margherita and Rocket Man.  Margherita arrived first. I was not impressed -- the tomato sauce was under-seasoned and lacked deeper umami taste.  My dining companion thought that the crust was not very satisfying because it did not have those slight chewiness developed with yeast.  Their ingredients tasted all very fresh -- and I enjoyed the combination of arugula and egg in Rocket Man, but I did not taste any lemon that was supposed to be one of ingredients in Rocket Man.

Although staff there were friendly and courteous, there was some issues with services.  The first pizza arrived reasonably quickly, but we waited another 15+ minutes to get the second pie.  If we ordered a salad and a pizza, I can expect a wait between courses -- it did not make sense to me that we get one pizza at a time.  The restaurant was about 60-70% occupied -- but we saw that quite a few people came to pick up a large order of takeout when waiting for our food.  Is it possible that the kitchen was giving priority to take-out customers over dine-in ones?  

Overrated.
author: Ryoko M.

description: I love how close PizzaHacker is to my house! It's crazy how all these hipster places have been opening up in the neighborhood lately, but I guess I'll just go with the flow... since the flow comes with good food! Considering these pizzas can be small enough to be individual size, it's a bit pricey running at $15 a piece, but if you share it's totally a steal. My bf and I shared the Yo, Vinny! - marinated onions, peppers, house Italian sausage, tomato sauce and fresh mozzarella... we also added chorizo and black olives. The sauce was great and the crust was so good! I usually don't like crust, but I liked this one so that's really saying something. I didn't get a chance to try the other pizzas but they looked promising... and the beer menu looks great too! I'll definitely be back.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Update: went in for take out again and MAN was it busier than ever! This is just an update on the take out process....worked so smooth and our pizzas were ready exactly when they said so. Came in, paid, got my pizzas, and left. Everyone was SUPER friendly and nice and calm even with it being a bit of a madhouse
Oh, and the pizza of course is still awesome.
author: A S.

description: their kale caesar is amazing and the reason i go there. the pizza is good, as well, but the kale caesar is the highlight. friendly staff; definitely kid friendly place with the chalkboard and all. again, have the kale caesar... i want to drink their pizza sauce...straight up.
author: Vicki T.

description:
My boyfriend and I were super excited to try Longbridge Pizza but the owner came out and told us the electricity was out! He was super bummed about it since it was a Saturday night and they just opened but he said his buddy had a place called PizzaHacker "with the same kind of dough" 

We sat around in our car looking at yelp for other options and 20 options later we ended with PizzaHacker -___- Should've just gone with it to begin with! We drove to Bernal Heights (it was crackin that night! WTF a line to get in everywhere. Whats happening to this neighborhood?!) and after finally finding parking, we still entertained ourselves with different options. We looked at BluePlate but I didn't like their menu and tried to get a table at the new ICHI location but there was a two hour wait (dafuq) so again, PizzaHacker it was!

This place is communal seating only and its decorated with christmas lights and high ceilings so I felt like I was eating outside the whole time! They also have a chalk board wall that anyone can draw on and an open kitchen and very small bar area. 

We got the top shelf margherita (only 20 made a day!) and considered getting a salad. Their salad was $10 so our fat logic concluded we could practically get another pizza for that price so two pizzas it was! We got the Spinach Man 3? and that was by far my favorite. My boyfriend knew I would like it as soon as he bit into it because it was spicy aka way too spicy for him so he practically ate the entire marghertia himself. We were talking about how we could eat the leftovers for breakfast the next day BUT THERE WERE NO LEFTOVERS! I wasn't even hungry and I ate an entire pizza to myself. My bottomless pit of a stomach has won again. 

We got two glasses of the blend aka the cheapest wine they have on the menu. They also have bottles, carafes, and beer. The wine looked like a bigger serving than usual but it might've been an illusion to satiate my alcoholic eyes. 

A mexican band randomly walked in and started playing music and I was rocking out too hard to not tip them when they walked around with their little plastic bag to all the tables. Love me some live music on date night. Crust was very crusty and the waitress gave me a weird look when I asked her for a side of pizza sauce how else am I supposed to eat the crust?!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Hands down best pizza in the city- do pickup or eat in with a tasty beer. I eat here way too often #worthit
author: Mariana P.

description:
I know, I know. I'm kind of bringing down the mood in the PizzaHacker review feed, raining on the proverbial parade. But hear me out - if the good people behind this place (and in front of it, for that matter) this pick up what I'm layin' down, beautiful things could happen here. 

I'm not a local - in fact I was a good 2,000 miles from home when I walked into PH. So I got the scoop on its background from the friends I was dining with, and suddenly it all made sense: PizzaHacker was the product of a food truck putting on the breaks and taking up a less mobile home in this space. The problem is - that's exactly what it feels like. 

On a food truck, the emphasis is on creating memorable, craving-inducing street eats. It also can't hurt to be friendly with those who wander up to your truck to create a sense of loyalty. It seems PH had these two aspects down pat, and they translated perfectly to the new space.  Our server was a great guy, attentive and welcoming. The owner was on hand touching tables and hanging out with guests. The menu is simple, sticking to what they do best - thin crusts that somehow manage to be both crunchy and soft at the same time topped with innovative ingredients (with the requisite clever monikers, to boot). The Heavy Nettle was a massive hit - foraged nettles are a seriously rad pizza topping; who knew? Don't expect heavy toppings here - they're going for balance and I love it. With gourmet ingredients like these, I don't want a blanket of cheese to overpower it all.

Rating solely on food and service, I would have given them 4.5 stars. But when dining (and especially if  I'm going to pay $15/pizza), I'm looking for a full experience - and the atmosphere at PH needs a little help. I love the fun touch of the lights strung overhead, and I don't even mind the picnic table style seating. But when the dining room only gets a decent cleaning at the end of the night (napkins fell on the floor and stayed there, tables remained un-bussed for long periods of time, the singular bathroom for the entire place had standing water on the floor and was in pretty bad shape), the experience starts to suffer. 

In general, the space had an unfinished feeling - extra supplies lying out in the open, disorganized shelving where items just hadn't found a permanent home yet, and a starkness that left it feeling a little cold despite what could have easily been a more festive environment. Some adjustment with the lighting and the addition of something to soak up a little sound (it gets really loud with even a small crowd) would do wonders. 

And finally I have to mention the house red wine - an excellent value, but my god does it taste like straight up grape juice! If you love a sweet red, you're all set (and many of the pies are spicy, so a little sweet can't hurt I guess). I get that this is definitely a beer kind of place, but I'd love to see the wine list expand a little to create more interesting pairing with the pizzas. 

The good news, PizzaHacker? You're off to a great start. Hoping to be back to the Left Coast soon to check on your progress and try a few more of your creations.
author: Amanda H.

description: This place may be a little bit overhyped, but they do have very good pizza. I wish they had more of a variety of salads and side dishes on the menu to round the meal out. Definitely plan to get here on the early side if you don't want to wait.
author: Diana G.

description: Ordered two pizzas one night last week.  Both crusts were quite burned... literally black.  Outside of that, the rest of the pizza was fine.  Not a good start for a first-time customer.  I will give them another try down.
author: Eddie G.

description:
After having what is arguably the best pizza in the world in Italy, I pretty much stayed away from any and all pizza once I came back home. If that makes me a pizza snob, so be it. With that said, I'd been eyeing PizzaHacker for awhile and it seemed like it was worth a try.

My family and I arrived during prime-time on a Friday night and after adding my name on the chalkboard, we waited about 15-20 minutes for a table to open up. PizzaHacker is all about the communal tables and casual dining all while offering fresh and organic pizzas and salads - my kinda place.

We shared a "top shelf" margherita pizza ($15) and a medium kale caesar salad ($8), which were more than enough for 3 people although I think we could've had another pizza. The pizza was beyond better than what I expected. It was so similar to my beloved pizza in Florence and I wanted it all to myself. What I loved most about it was the sauce - it was fresh and just a little sweet. If you can't make a great margherita pizza, then something is wrong; PizzaHacker's is just right. While I loved the pizza, the real show-stopper was the kale caesar salad. I need to eat this every day. Do not skip out on ordering this salad!

I know that PizzaHacker has been in Bernal Heights for awhile now but it is honestly a welcome addition to the neighborhood, more so now because the pizza place I've been going to for years has decided to stop delivering to this part of the city. PizzaHacker, looks like you're my new go-to ;)
author: Stephanie C.

description: Love it! Their pizza is delicious and I love the Intermezzo is awesome. Just wish they had regular sodas like Coke & Diet Coke.
author: j-lo G.

description:
Pizza is fantastic! Came here a couple months ago with a group of co-workers, and we tried just about every pizza on the menu. All were delicious, especially the top shelf margherita and the one with the egg in the middle.

Went back last week and again had my mind blown.

This place has my vote for best pizza in the Bay!
author: Dave S.

description: Simple menu, 7-8ish pizzas and two salads. The Shortbridge is our favorite, admittingly we have only tried two others, both of which were delish. We live the lake Cesar, but the other salad is great also!!
author: Brooke B.

description: I recently counted at least 48 pizza places that I've been to in the city. Hacker is one of my top favorites! The Top Shelf Margherita and the Rocket Man are my favorite pizzas there, but I've never had one that I didn't enjoy. The crust is perfect - chewy and crispy and flavorful. The tomato sauce on the margherita is tangy and delicious. Super kid-friendly place too. Love it. I live in Russian Hill and it's worth the drive!
author: Amy C.

description:
3.75 stars rounded up

The building at 3299 Mission Street has been reincarnated into Pizza Hacker's home. I remember it previously as a Peruvian restaurant & a bank even before that, but this was my first time setting foot inside. 

Communal picnic tables (though we scored one big enough just for the two of us) & four counter seats were all occupied when we arrive an hour before closing. Skylights & lofty ceilings set an outdoorsy vibe, Christmas lights scream "backyard boogie." Booming music, no doubt of the underground variety, & hipster staff round out this scene which isn't for everyone. 

The top shelf marg, which is made in limited quantities was sold out, & the mission fig-topped pizza I'd obsessed about was no longer on the menu. We ordered: 
-- a couple ibita root beers 
-- rocket man: arugala, egg, garlic, lemon juice, fresh mozzarella, chili paste. I added tomato sauce b/c I really wanted that flavor. The verdant freshness of lemon juice really stood out. If you're looking for runny egg yolk porn, you're SOL here; our egg was medium hard & not oozy at all (which was fine by me, but disappointed my companion.) 
-- yo vinny: marinated onions, goat horn peppers, sausage, tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella: he added on an egg, & it was the same medium hard situation. I liked this pizza better than my choice because it had more flavor & more spice. 
-- dessert was Mitchell's chocolate ice cream drizzled with bergamot infused olive oil & sea salt: I'm not usually a fan of citrus (especially citrus mixed with chocolate), but this was an all-around good mix of flavors. 

Aloof, but fast service. Hipster-cool atmosphere. Chalkboard menu. So-so pizzas with chewy/thickish crust for being thin crust. I feel some ambivalence towards the taste of their pizzas, but I could see this place growing on me.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I've been coming here since before it was formally open. I'll keep it brief:

This is some of the best pizza you will taste. It is nothing short of amazing. The crust is sublime. 

Background: I am a New Jersey-born pizza snob who does not go for frou-frou noveau pizza. But PizzaHacker is in a class by itself. You can go to fancier places, and you can definitely pay a whole lot more elsewhere. But dollar for dollar, this may be the best pizza you'll ever taste in your short time in this world.
author: Telstar L.

description: The Rocketman pizza was delicious and came out fast. Beers were good, service by Corey was great, and I had maybe the best chocolate ice cream I've ever had. I only wish they were open later.
author: Carla C.

description: Ive missed enough of PH's pop ups. Im glad there is a shop I can pop into now. I was in the area, already had dinner but as a True Gourmand, I can always eat more. Split a Yo Vinny with a friend... Marinated onions, goat horn peppers, 4505 hot Italian sausage, tomato sauce & fresh mozzarella. Thin, crisp crust, decent chew and nice balance of ingredients. A fine pie may I say. SF is picking up in the pizza arena and Im always glad a good new player steps up.
author: Kim N.

description: Quirky location,  casual setting so good to go with friends or a date,  I went with my boyfriend and we shared the Rocket Man. I love pizza have been to alot of the top locations in Sf and this pizza is really different high quality pizza, I'm just losing a star because we added Italian Sausage for an extra 4$ I think or more and it did not play a significant part of the pizza.  I would have loved a little bit more sausage when you pay a decent bit for it as an extra topping! Will give it another shot and go for something else! FYI for cheese lovers this is not your typical cheesy pizza.  Good service also!
author: Nadia H.

description:
Wow. Just left the soft opening of the new Pizza Hacker brick & mortar on Mission. I couldn't be more impressed. As a Delfina loyalist, it is hard to admit that this might be the best pizza I have had in SF (or anywhere for that matter). 

First and foremost, the crust is perfect. Perfectly crispy, perfectly doughy, perfectly charred. Just perfect. 

Secondly, although it may be even more defining than the crust itself, is that the toppings don't overwhelm the crust. While still tasting the unique combinations of toppings on each pizza, you don't lose the crispiness or flavor of the crust. 

We shared the "Crowd Pleaser" & the "Get A Room." The Crowd Pleaser was great. With no tomato sauce, radiccho, dried figs, Point Reye's blue cheese & onion, it tasted almost like a crostini-pizza hybrid. No complaints here.

The Get A Room, however, was the hands-down favorite (although we finished both pizzas without hesitation-an unusual feat for two small, eyes-bigger-than-their-stomach type of chicks). It's tomato & mozz were fabulous, and it didn't have too much of either. The Spanish chorizo, red onions, olives and hot cherry peppers were all in perfect proportion and married together wonderfully.
